text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
THE MUSLIM
- President Farooq Leghari said that no sect but a foreign hand was involved in sectarian violence in Punjab. He urged the govenment to crush the terrorist elements.
THE NEWS
- Police baton-charged opposition Pakistan People's Party workers at district courts.
THE NATION
- A group of 25 people gangraped 15 ladies and molested boys of a rival tribe in Soon Topa village near Rawalakot in Azad Kashmir.
DAWN
- The government has allowed another private airline to operate flights on domestic routes.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif appointed a 12-member National Council for Engineering and Industrial Coordination to strengthen industrial structure and reduce the import of engineering goods.

- The judiciary cannot remain a silent spectator to the situation prevailing in the country, which is engaged in a struggle for survival, Chief Justice Sajjad Ali Shah told a seminar on the 50th year of journalism in Pakistan.
- A Pakistan Law Commission report on jail reforms has recommended that the government abolish whipping and putting bar fetters on prisoners.
- A Foreign Office spokesman has expressed satisfaction with the expression of regret and apology communicated by the Fairfax County Attorney Robert Horan in a letter to the Prime Minister.
- Shaheen Roohi Bukhari, deputy editor of an Urdu daily, was taken into custody by Quetta police in a subversion case.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- The prices of palm oil have shot up 100 rupees ($2.46) per maund (37.32 kg) to 1,255 in the last two days.
- The government may empower the Privatisation Commission to handle all matters relating to privatisation in future.
- Karachi is one of the 10 cities of the world where people are believed to be most exposed to high lead levels causing them physical and mental sufferings of different kinds
- ABN-AMRO Bank will expand its operations in Pakistan and the new strategy under the plan-2000 will be completed within a few months.
FINANCIAL POST
- The Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Resources has asked the government to restore the fiscal concessions under the National Mineral Policy 1995.
-- Islamabad newsroom 9251-274757
